Situation1: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Expectation2: Show love and kindness to others, following the teachings of Jesus
Situation2: They offer small gestures of kindness in daily interactions
Story: I sat in the cramped break room, my lunch barely touched, eyes scanning the latest pharmacy newsletter. New drugs, new protocols—so much to keep up with. I knew my patients depended on me to be knowledgeable, to give them the best care. Just as I was reading about a promising new medication, I heard a soft sniffle from the hallway. Glancing up, I saw Mrs. Evans, a regular, standing by the counter, her shoulders shaking. She looked so small and lost. My heart ached; as a Christian, I felt the pull to comfort her, to offer a listening ear and a gentle word, just as Jesus would. But the clock was ticking, and I had only a few minutes left on my break. If I didn’t finish reading, I might miss something crucial for my patients’ safety. The weight of both expectations pressed on me—my duty to stay informed, and my calling to show love. I sat frozen, torn between the pages in my hand and the woman who needed kindness.
